newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks close higher despite protests.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks close higher despite protests.

text.p: Despite a rowdy protest that shut down floor trading for three hours, Mexican stocks closed at historic new highs on Wednesday as the combination of low interest rates, a strong peso and rosy economic sentiment continued to work their magic, traders said.
The IPC index of leading stocks closed 0.31 percent or 10.58 points higher to 3,412.37 points, snapping Tuesday's record closing high of 3,401.79 points.
"It was a big success, really," one trader said. "It's a shame we had this problem. Who knows would have happened otherwise?"

About 200 student protesters and parents blocked the main entrances to the stock exchange building, scaring off traders and bolsa officials before the opening bell at 0830 local time/0930 EDT/1330 GMT. But then about 30 or 40 riot police cleared the way to a back door, allowing personnel to enter.
Electronic trading began on time, but with barely any volume. When floor trading by open outcry finally began at 1130 local time/1230 EDT, stock prices soared.
Within minutes, the IPC index peaked at 3,432.13 points, setting a new intraday standard, before gradually winding down in the afternoon.
